description: From Middle English swete, swet, swate, swote, from Old English swāt, from Proto-Germanic *swait-, *swaitą, from Proto-Indo-European *swoyd- (“to sweat”), o-grade of *sweyd- (“to sweat”). Cognate with West Frisian swit, Dutch zweet, German Schweiß, Danish sved, Swedish svett, Yiddish שוויצן‎ (shvitsn) (English shvitz), Latin sudor, French sueur, Italian sudore, Spanish sudor, Persian خوی‎ (xway, “sweat”), Sanskrit स्वेद (svéda), Lithuanian sviedri, Tocharian B syā-, Albanian djersë, and Welsh chwys.

entries.meaning: Fluid that exits the body through pores in the skin usually due to physical stress and/or high temperature for the purpose of regulating body temperature and removing certain compounds from the circulation.
examples: Synonym: perspiration

entries.meaning: The state of one who sweats; diaphoresis.
examples: Just thinking about the interview tomorrow puts me into a nervous sweat.

entries.meaning: (figurative) Hard work; toil.
(figurative) Moisture issuing from any substance.
examples: The Muses' friend (grey-eyed Aurora) yet  Held all the meadows in a cooling sweat,  The milk-white gossamers not upwards snow'd,  Nor was the sharp and useful-steering goad

entries.meaning: A short run by a racehorse as a form of exercise.
examples: A Horſe that gains Fleſh in hard Exerciſe, should be ſweated at leaſt twice in ten Days; and he ſhould run near five Miles in Puſhes, that the Sweat may have Time to diſcharge. Those Horſes which are ſweat without Covering, or with a very thin one, should run a long Sweat, as wel call it, and ſtand a conſiderable while afterwards with a thick Blanket or two over them, from Head to Tail; otherwiſe the Sweat will not come out well.

entries.meaning: (historical) The sweating sickness.
examples: When the sweat comes back this summer, 1528, people say, as they did last year, that you won't get it if you don't think about it.

entries.meaning: (Britain, military slang, especially WWI) A soldier (especially one who is old or experienced).
(video games, slang) An extremely competitive player.

description: From Middle English sweten, from Old English swǣtan, from Proto-Germanic *swaitijaną (“to sweat”). Compare Dutch zweten, German schwitzen, Danish svede. Doublet of shvitz.

verbs.description: sweat (third-person singular simple present sweats, present participle sweating, simple past and past participle sweated or sweat)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To emit sweat.
examples: Synonym: perspire

definitionGroups.group: (transitive) To cause to excrete moisture through skin.

entries.meaning: To cause to perspire.
examples: His physicians attempted to sweat him by most powerful sudorifics.

entries.meaning: (video games) To be extremely dedicated to winning a game; to play competitively.
examples: Synonym: tryhard
There's no way we can win. These guys are sweating so hard.

entries.meaning: (transitive, informal) To extract money, labour, etc. from, by exaction or oppression.
examples: to sweat a spendthrift
to sweat labourers

entries.meaning: (intransitive, informal) To worry.
examples: Synonyms: fret, worry

entries.meaning: (transitive, informal) To worry about (something). [from 20th c.]
examples: Don't sweat it!
to sweat the small stuff

entries.meaning: (transitive) To emit, in the manner of sweat.
examples: to sweat blood

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To emit moisture.
examples: The cheese will start sweating if you don't refrigerate it.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To have drops of water form on (something's surface) due to moisture condensation.
examples: Coasters are a good way to stop a sweating glass from damaging your table.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, plumbing) To solder (a pipe joint) together.
(transitive, slang) To stress out.
examples: Stop sweatin'  me!

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive, cooking) To cook slowly at low heat, in shallow oil and without browning, to reduce moisture content.
(transitive, archaic) To remove a portion of (a coin), as by shaking it with others in a bag, so that the friction wears off a small quantity of the metal.
examples: The only use of it [money] which is interdicted is to put it in circulation again after having diminished its weight by sweating, or otherwise, because the quantity of metal contains is no longer consistent with its impression.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To suffer a penalty; to smart for one's misdeeds.
(transitive) To take a racehorse for a short exercise run.
examples: A Horſe that gains Fleſh in hard Exerciſe, should be ſweated at leaſt twice in ten Days; and he ſhould run near five Miles in Puſhes, that the Sweat may have Time to diſcharge. Those Horſes which are ſweat without Covering, or with a very thin one, should run a long Sweat, as wel call it, and ſtand a conſiderable while afterwards with a thick Blanket or two over them, from Head to Tail; otherwiſe the Sweat will not come out well.
